H0.text: Floods are most likely to cause an increase in diseases transmitted by water in ecosystems where people live.

H1.text: Blizzards are most likely to cause an increase in diseases transmitted by water in ecosystems where people live.

H2.text: Hailstorms are most likely to cause an increase in diseases transmitted by water in ecosystems where people live.

H3.text: Avalanches are the most likely to cause an increase in diseases transmitted by water in ecosystems where people live.

A4.text: Clean water supplies are often contaminated when flooding occurs. Hepatitis A and E are common because of the lack of sanitation in the water and in living quarters, depending on where the flood is and how prepared the community is for a flood.

A5.text: Vector-borne diseases also increase, due to the residual still water after the floods have settled. The diseases that are vector borne are malaria, dengue, West Nile, and yellow fever.
